and of course: the magic forge.

it's very expensive to use, so it's

it's my duty to help you four,
\p3Say... can we get to crafting right now?
\willI was out at the abandoned mine
that's just north of town a bit ago.

ambushed by a group of monsters! I was
able to escape, but I dropped a lot of
\willYou can go and grab the items
while I set up the forge for
So We Back In The Mine

probably want to do a bit of
Now you'll be able to mine ores!
You can tell if an ore is mineable
if it has a pickaxe icon above it.
\willJust to recap: go to the mine north
of town. If you keep heading north in
town, there's no way you'll miss
\willOnce you're in there, mine some ores,
but focus on getting to the back where
\willI'll sell you a few items at
Do you need anything from me?

rushing back here without the items
isn't going to do anything for you.
\willYep! All intact! Thank you so much!
So We Back In The Mine

would prepare the forge for you. Feel

thing that I'll need you to note.
weapons or equipment, you won't be

for longer than the Smiths have been present.
If you want to find him, it's going to
be tough to get any information
is your best bet for finding anything
here, I'd love to speak with you more.
Trust me, there is a lot more to the

interact with that table in front of the

the other side of the counter?
Do you need anything from me?
or some gods... but anything works.
\willWell, I'm no scholar in that area
of history... but my family has kept
the history of the Blazing Sands safe
\willDue to my profession, I also know
a few other special things about the
\willOne of these is the age of the Overworld.
Analysis of sediments and other products of age
have revealed the Overworld to be very, very, VERY
old. Hundreds of thousands, at the very least.
\willWhen I first learned of this, that got
me thinking... isn't it odd that with all
that preparation, we still managed to lose
the war a thousand years ago?
was unmatched, but you'd think that
with all that time to develop, we
wouldn't have been crushed THIS bad.
clearly built by humans, but when, and by
who? We've lost all this history... but how?
wasn't the first one, and maybe it won't
humanity, but has failed time and time again.
\p3No, no, I understand. I have my own
crazy theories too. This one, though...
you might really be onto something?
\willReally? Well, I'm glad that my random
thoughts were of some use to you.
\willBut assuming that you four will be
the ones preventing the Great Collapse
\will\c[18]Apocalypse\c[0] is said to be a swordsman
like you. As the most likely candidate to
be the chosen knight, you'll probably
end up in close-quarters combat with \c[18]him\c[0].
\willI know I've suggested this to you before,
but I'll say it once more: I think it's not
a bad idea to at least try to seek out the
\willThe First Knight... his sword is said
to be lost to time and space, but if you
were somehow able to find it, it would no
doubt be an asset to your journey.
\willI have no clue where it might be,
it might make the difference between

So, more about the Blazing Sands...
\willYou want to learn more about the
ancient history of the Blazing Sands?
a region home to prosperity and
magic. However, it's also home to
people to live here is the magic
\willI'm sure you four already know the
story of the great war that took place
\willDo you four know of that destroyed
fortress out in the Blazing Sands?
\willFor future reference, it's out in the east.
\willLong ago, nearing the end of the
great war, the fortress was one of
the last remaining bases for us
of the Overworld, and there were a scant
few places where us humans could have
down inside, holding the fort as
that had come looking for a safe haven,
but other than that, it was mostly
\willThe issue was, no matter how many
no matter how many fireballs the
the library, an adventurer found an
old, battered scroll; a scroll older
than anything else in the library.
\willWith the monsters banging on the door
and the time ticking, the magic users
to perform the ritual on the scroll.
\willEverything was set up, and the mages
gathered around the scroll and began
and a blast of light emerged from
\willEveryone was blinded, but as the light
faded from their eyes, they saw the door
blasted wide open, with not a single
They could run around outside! They
were free, even if only for a single
\willMany went on walks for hours, and
legends say that the sands glowed
\willWith a resupply of food and a breath
of fresh air, the soldiers and adventurers
returned to the fort satisfied, ready for
in and slaughtered every last person
was left to fend for itself.
\willThe magic in the sands kept the souls
of those poor soldiers living. Those souls
are most likely still wandering the halls
of the fort to this day.
wander those halls for all of eternity,
thanks to the doings of one of
\willIt's your job to go defeat the
\willI doubt you'll even be able to get
into the fort due to all the rubble.
\willI think I might know a way in. Key
word here is "might," but hey, anything
\willLegends have been passed down of an
ancient relic that has the power to
It is filled with the enchanted
direct control of time, only allowing
you to switch between the present and
\willIt supposedly is in tune with where
and when the sand was placed into it.
\willThis means that if it was created at
the fort, it most likely will only turn
time back at the fort and to the time
\willWith a name that has the word "Archaic"
in it, I think it's safe to bet that it's
pretty old. It should hopefully take you
to a time when the fort was in better repair.
\willThe legends say it should be at the
peak of the Great Pyramid. However, this
isn't confirmed, as no one has been
to the top of it for a long time.
\willI think this is your best bet, though.
Got that? Head to the Great Pyramid!
It should somewhere around the middle
